section.title: What is a distribution ?
section.para: Unix comes in many flavors, usually called distributionsdistributions. A distribution (or in short distro) is a collection of software packages, distributed on CD, online or pre-installed on computers. All the software in a distribution is tested and integrates nicely into a whole. Software is maintained (patched) by the distributor, and is managed by an integrated package managerintegrated package manager. Many distro's have a central repository of approved softwarerepository of approved software. Installing software from outside the distro can sometimes be cumbersome and may void your warranty on the system.

section.title: Major Vendors of Unix
section.para: We should at least mention IBM's AIXAIX, Sun's SolarisSolaris and Hewlett-Packards HP-UXHP-UX, all are based on the original Unix from Bell Labs (Unix System V). Sun's SunOSSunOS, HP's Tru64Tru64 (originally from DEC) and Apple's MacOSXMacOSX are more derived from the BSD branch. But most Unixes today may contain source code and implementations from both original Unix-branches.

section.title: Linux Distributions
section.para: There are hundreds of Linux distributions, just take a look at the distrowatch.com website. For many years, Red Hat, Suse and Mandrake were considered the big three for end users. Red Hat is still the biggest commercial Linux vendor, but in 2008, the most popular Linux distribution for home users is UbuntuUbuntu from Canonical.

section.title: Linux distribution detection
section.para: Depending on the distribution used, there are distinct files that contain the distribution version.

The /etc/redhat-release/etc/redhat-release file contains the Red Hat version on most of the Red Hat and Red Hat derived systems. Debian and Ubuntu systems contain /etc/debian-version/etc/debian-version. Note that Ubuntu was originally derived from Debian.
section.screen:
paul@RHELv4u4:~$ cat /etc/redhat-release Red Hat Enterprise Linux AS release 4 (Nahant Update 4)
serge@venusia:~$ cat /etc/debian_version lenny/sid
section.para: The /etc/lsb-release/etc/lsb-release file can be found on distributions that follow the Linux Standard Base. Other variations to these files are /etc/slackware-version/etc/slackware-version, /etc/SuSE-release/etc/SuSE-release, /etc/gentoo-release/etc/gentoo-release and /etc/mandrake-release/etc/mandriva-release.
section.screen: serge@venusia:~$ cat /etc/lsb-release DISTRIB_ID=Ubuntu DISTRIB_RELEASE=8.04 DISTRIB_CODENAME=hardy DISTRIB_DESCRIPTION="Ubuntu 8.04.1"

section.title: Red Hat
section.para: Redhat exists as a company since 1993. They distribute Red Hat Enterprise LinuxRed Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) to companies and manage the FedoraFedora project. RHEL is probably the most popular Linux-based distro on servers. Fedora is a very popular and user friendly Linux-based distro, aimed towards home users. The company makes a profit of around one hundred million dollars a year, selling support contracts. Red Hat contributes a lot to the Linux kernel and other free software projects.

section.title: Red Hat Linux
section.para: Red Hat Linux was distributed from 1994 until 2003. It was one of the oldest common Linux distributions. Red Hat Linux was the first distro to use the rpmrpm package format. Many other distro's are originally derived from Red Hat Linux. The company Red Hat, Inc.Red Hat, Inc. decided to split Red Hat Linux into FedoraFedora and Red Hat Enterprise LinuxRed Hat Enterprise Linux.

section.title: Fedora
section.para: FedoraFedora is sponsored by Red Hat, and is aimed toward home users. There is no official support from Red Hat. Every six to eight months, there is a new version of Fedora. Fedora usually has more recent versions of kernel and applications than RHEL. Fedora 9 was released May 2008.

section.title: Red Hat Enterprise Linux 4
section.para: Since 2005 Red Hat distributes four different RHEL4 variants. RHEL ASRHEL AS is for mission-critical computer systems. RHEL ESRHEL ES is for small to mid-range servers. RHEL WSRHEL WS is for technical power user desktops and critical design. Red Hat DesktopRed Hat Desktop is for multiple deployments of single user desktops. Red Hat does not give an explanation for the meaning of AS, ES and WS, but it might be Advanced Server, Entry-level Server and Workstation.

section.title: Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5
section.para: Red Hat Enterprise Linux version 5 is available since March 2007. One of the notable new features is the inclusion of XenXen. Xen is a free virtual machine application that allows modified NetBSD and Linux to serve as host for guest OS'ses. Beyond just virtualization, RHEL 5 also has better SELinux support, clustering, network storage and smartcard integration.

section.title: CentOS and Unbreakable Linux
section.para: Both CentOSCentOS and Oracle's Unbreakable LinuxUnbreakable Linux are directly derived from RHEL, but all references to Red Hat trademarks are removed. Companies are allowed to do this (GPL), and are hoping to make a profit selling support (without having the cost to maintain and develop their own distribution). Red Hat is not really worried about this, since they develop a lot on Linux, and thus can offer much better support. The Oracle offer however is still very recent, let's wait and see how many organizations will buy a complete solution from Oracle.

section.title: Ubuntu
section.para: UbuntuUbuntu is a rather new distribution, based on Debiandebian and funded by South African developer and billionaire astronaut Mark ShuttleworthMark Shuttleworth. Ubuntu is giving away free (as in beer and speech) CD's with Ubuntu, Linux for Human BeingsUbuntu, Linux for Human Beings. Many people consider Ubuntu to be the most user friendly Linux distribution. The company behind Ubuntu is CanonicalCanonical, they aim to make a profit of selling support soon. Ubuntu is probably the most popular Unix-like distribution on personal desktops.

section.title: Novell Suse
section.para: A couple of years ago, NovellNovell bought the German company SuseSuse. They are seen as the main competitor to Red Hat with their SLES (Suse Linux Enterprise Server) and SLED (Suse Linux Enterprise Desktop) versions of Suse Linux. Similar to Fedora, Novell hosts the OpenSUSEOpenSUSE project as a testbed for upcoming SLED and SLES releases.

Novell has signed a very controversial deal with Microsoft. Some high profile open source developers have left the company because of this agreement, and many people from the open source community are actively advocating to abandon Novell completely.

section.title: Debian
section.para: Debian is one of the most secure Linux distro's. It is known to be stable and reliable. The Debian people also have a strong focus towards freedom. You will not find patented technologies or non-free software in the standard Debian repositories. A lot of distributions (Ubuntu, Knoppix, ...) are derived from the Debian codebase. Debian has aptitudeaptitude(1), which is considered the best package management system.

section.title: Mandriva
section.para: Mandriva is the unification of the Brazilian distro Conectiva with the French distro Mandrake. They are considered a user friendly distro, with support from the French government.

section.title: FreeBSD
section.para: FreeBSDFreeBSD is a complete operating system. The kernel and all of the utilities are held in the same source code tree. FreeBSD runs on many architectures and is considered to be reliable and robust. Millions of websites are running on FreeBSD, including some big like yahoo.com, apache.org, sony.co.jp, netcraft, php.net, freebsd.org and (until last year) ftp.cdrom.com. Apple's MacOSX contains the FreeBSD virtual file system, network stack and more.

section.title: NetBSD
section.para: NetBSDNetBSD development started around the same time (1993) as FreeBSD. NetBSD aims for maximum portability and thus runs on many architectures. NetBSD is often used in embedded devices.

section.title: OpenBSD
section.para: Co-founder Theo De RaadtTheo De Raadt from NetBSD founded the OpenBSDOpenBSD project in 1994. OpenBSD aims for maximum security. The past ten years, only two vulnerabilities were found in the default install of OpenBSD. All source code is thoroughly checked. OpenBSD runs on sixteen different architectures and is commonly used for firewalls and IDS. The OpenBSD people also bring us OpenSSHOpenSSH.

section.title: Solaris 8 and Solaris 9
section.para: All Sun SolarisSun Solaris releases before Solaris 10 are proprietary binary only, just like IBM AIX and HP-UX.

section.title: Solaris 10
section.para: Solaris 10 is the officialy supported Sun distribution. It is a free (as in beer) download. Sun releases binary patches and updates. Sun would like a community built around the solaris kernel, similar to the Linux community. Sun released the Solaris kernel under the CDDL, a license similar to the GPL, hoping this will happen.

section.title: Nevada and Solaris Express
section.para: Nevada is the codename for the next release of Solaris (Solaris 11). It is currently under development by Sun and is based on the OpenSolaris code. Solaris Express Community Edition is an official free binary release including open source OpenSolaris and some closed source technologies, updated twice a month without any support from Sun. Solaris Express Developer Edition is the same, but with some support, thorough testing before release, and released twice a year.

section.title: OpenSolaris, Belenix and Nexenta
section.para: OpenSolaris is een open source development project (yes, it is only source code). Future versions of the Solaris operating system are based on this source code. The BelenixBelenix LiveCD is based on OpenSolaris. Another famous opensolaris based distro is NexentaNexenta. Nexenta (www.gnusolaris.org) looks like UbuntuUbuntu and feels like DebianDebian. The goal of this GNU/SolarisGNU/Solaris project is to have the best Linux desktop (Ubuntu) including the aptitudeaptitude package manager running on a Sun Solaris kernel.
